pullrequest.title: Logging Part 4: Query messages based on topic name or time

content.raw:
We sort-of follow google's style guide. If we follow their recommendations for enum names then this should either be like a constant `kInclusive` or like a macro `INCLUSIVE`. I'll change it to macro style since it matches #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/98afd39f6638b047b9d752c4542293b0eafd33cb/include/ignition/transport/AdvertiseOptions.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#AdvertiseOptions.hh-37

https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Enumerator_Names

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 4: Query messages based on topic name or time

content.raw:
To make it compile we would need to say

```
const QualifiedTime::Time * QualifiedTime::GetTime() const
```

I was feeling especially lazy when I wrote this member function definition.
content.html:
To make it compile we would need to say

const QualifiedTime::Time * QualifiedTime::GetTime() const

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 4: Query messages based on topic name or time

content.raw: For what it's worth, I usually do this when the return type is a nested typedef within a class. It saves a **ton** of trouble and makes code much cleaner with templated classes, so I would encourage people to get familiar and comfortable with the syntax, even if we want to typically avoid using it.
content.html: For what it's worth, I usually do this when the return type is a nested typedef within a class. It saves a ton of trouble and makes code much cleaner with templated classes, so I would encourage people to get familiar and comfortable with the syntax, even if we want to typically avoid using it.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 4: Query messages based on topic name or time

content.raw:
I'm assuming that if both `QualifiedTime` are indeterminate you want to return `true` here. In that case, does it matter the value of `qualifier` and `time`?

It might be the case that the two times are different, then, you call `Clear()` on both of them. I believe that in this case, this function would return `false` as it is.
content.html:
I'm assuming that if both QualifiedTime are indeterminate you want to return true here. In that case, does it matter the value of qualifier and time?

It might be the case that the two times are different, then, you call Clear() on both of them. I believe that in this case, this function would return false as it is.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 4: Query messages based on topic name or time

content.raw: Oh good catch! It should really check if they're both indeterminate first, and then perform this comparison.
content.html: Oh good catch! It should really check if they're both indeterminate first, and then perform this comparison.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 4: Query messages based on topic name or time

content.raw:
After thinking about this a little more, I think indeterminate times should [behave like NaN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NaN) when it comes to comparisons.

Consider the use-case of a `QualifiedTimeRange`. If both the start and the end are indeterminate, and those `QualifiedTime` objects compared as equal, it would imply that the entire time range is a single time point, but in reality it's the entire range of time.

I think NaN is the closest existing precedent for this time of value specification, so mimicking the established behavior of NaN seems like the most reasonable choice.

I'll change this comparison to handle indeterminate times like they're NaNs, unless you have an objection.
content.html:
After thinking about this a little more, I think indeterminate times should behave like NaN when it comes to comparisons.

Consider the use-case of a QualifiedTimeRange. If both the start and the end are indeterminate, and those QualifiedTime objects compared as equal, it would imply that the entire time range is a single time point, but in reality it's the entire range of time.

I think NaN is the closest existing precedent for this time of value specification, so mimicking the established behavior of NaN seems like the most reasonable choice.

I'll change this comparison to handle indeterminate times like they're NaNs, unless you have an objection.

content.raw: Consider to replace the last four instructions with `EXPECT_EQ(qt2, qt1)`. Leave the equality check for its own test.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 4: Query messages based on topic name or time

content.raw:
I added the equality expectation here: 241e30c

But I left in the rest of these tests, because I think there's value in individually verifying each data member after a copy. It would be unfortunate if we hit a weird case where copying somehow allowed two objects to compare as equal, even if the member data doesn't come out as expected.

(I'd rather have redundant testing than risk the chance of missing a weird edge case.)
content.html:
I added the equality expectation here: 241e30c

But I left in the rest of these tests, because I think there's value in individually verifying each data member after a copy. It would be unfortunate if we hit a weird case where copying somehow allowed two objects to compare as equal, even if the member data doesn't come out as expected.

(I'd rather have redundant testing than risk the chance of missing a weird edge case.)
